content.raw: The specific changeset kacper is referencing was correct when he made that comment but now needs to be different. You should be able to select it from the dropdown box in the destination branch dialog in the pull request edit interface. Right now the correct destination head is the one that contains changeset fffa77d. When the yt branch has more than one head like it does now, I usually take a look at the changeset graph (https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/commits/) when making the PR to check which head I should be landing on.

I think we want these to be loaded independently -- otherwise we'll end up having some duplication of memory.  And parameters should probably be as small as we can make it.  Same for connectivity.
content.html: I think we want these to be loaded independently -- otherwise we'll end up having some duplication of memory. And parameters should probably be as small as we can make it. Same for connectivity.

content.raw: This looks to be loading in all the variables -- we want that to just be done by the io handler.
content.html: This looks to be loading in all the variables -- we want that to just be done by the io handler.

content.raw: I think that we don't want to do this, because this could potentially be more data than can fit memory if the dataset is big enough. The _read_fluid_selection method of IOHandlerExodusII should take care of loading the data that is asked for, as it is needed.
content.html: I think that we don't want to do this, because this could potentially be more data than can fit memory if the dataset is big enough. The _read_fluid_selection method of IOHandlerExodusII should take care of loading the data that is asked for, as it is needed.

content.raw: @astrohckr could you upload files that you're using to http://use.yt/upload/?
content.html: @astrohckr could you upload files that you're using to http://use.yt/upload/?

content.raw: I get a 404 when I try to go to that URL.
content.html: I get a 404 when I try to go to that URL.

content.raw:
The files need to be uploaded using the curldrop:


```
#!bash

$ curl -T file.name http://use.yt/upload/
```

The trailing backslash at the end of the URL needs to be included.  I think the plan is to eventually add these instructions to use.yt/upload but for now you just need to remember it or have someone tell you.
content.html:
The files need to be uploaded using the curldrop:

$ curl -T file.name http://use.yt/upload/

The trailing backslash at the end of the URL needs to be included. I think the plan is to eventually add these instructions to use.yt/upload but for now you just need to remember it or have someone tell you.

content.html: All files are in place, when you change requires_ds to requires_file tests should be triggered automatically.

description:
## Description ##

This adds the ability to load Exodus II datasets into yt:

* Read from netcdf4 files, e.g. generated from the [MOOSE](http://mooseframework.org) framework
* Load connectivity and coordinate data into Unstructured Meshes
* Load fluid data

[Exodus II](http://prod.sandia.gov/techlib/access-control.cgi/1992/922137.pdf) is a data model developed by Sandia National Labs and is used to store/retrieve finite element meshes.

The most widely-used implementation of this data model utilizes the [NetCDF-4](http://www.hdfgroup.org/projects/netCDF-4/) container. It is for this reason that this frontend has been developed with this format in mind.

## Setup ##

You will need:

* [netcdf4-python](https://github.com/Unidata/netcdf4-python) 

## Example ##

Example notebook: [here](http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/astrohckr/bcbc493efd9b01191571)

You can load variables on demand rather than load all of them into the parameters dict.

Let's say you load an Exodus II data file (e.g. with extensions `*.e` or `*.e-*` file):

```
import yt
ds = yt.load("/path/to/exodus_file_that_ends_in.e")
```

To get list of all the variable keys:

```
ds.io_handler._get_variable_keys()
```

To read a specific variable:

```
ds.io_handler._read_variable('elem_num_map')[:]
```
